cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
When the egg is released from the ovary, what is left behind?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
When an egg is released from the ovary during the process of ovulation, it is part of the menstrual cycle in females. The ovary contains follicles, which are fluid-filled sacs that house immature eggs (oocytes). Each month, typically one follicle matures and releases an egg. Once the egg is released, the remaining structure of the follicle transforms into a structure called the corpus luteum. The corpus luteum produces hormones, primarily progesterone, which are essential for maintaining the uterine lining in case of pregnancy. If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum eventually degenerates.

Answer:
The corpus luteum is left behind in the ovary after the egg is released.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
When the egg is released from the ovary, what is left behind?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['After being released from the ovary, the egg is swept into the fallopian tube by the fimbria, which is a fringe of tissue at the end of each fallopian tube. After about a day, an unfertilized egg will disintegrate or dissolve in the fallopian tube.\n', 'The release of an oocyte does not alternate between the two ovaries and seems to be random. After removal of an ovary, the remaining one produces an egg every month.\n', 'Once a month, one of the ovaries releases a mature egg (ovum), known as an oocyte. The nucleus of such an oocyte is called a "germinal vesicle (see picture)."\n', 'Ovulation is the release of eggs from the ovaries. In humans, this event occurs when the ovarian follicles rupture and release the secondary oocyte ovarian cells. After ovulation, during the luteal phase, the egg will be available to be fertilized by sperm. In addition, the uterine lining (endometrium) is thickened to be able to receive a fertilized egg. If no conception occurs, the uterine lining as well as blood will be shed during menstruation.\n', 'The ova, which are the female sex cells, are much larger than the sperm and are normally formed within the ovaries of the fetus before its birth. They are mostly fixed in location within the ovary until their transit to the uterus, and contain nutrients for the later zygote and embryo. Over a regular interval, in response to hormonal signals, a process of oogenesis matures one ovum which is released and sent down the Fallopian tube. If not fertilized, this egg is released through menstruation in humans and other great apes, and reabsorbed in other mammals in the estrus cycle.\n', 'Usually, ovulation occurs in one of the two ovaries releasing an egg each menstrual cycle; however, if there was a case where one ovary was absent or dysfunctional then the other ovary would continue providing eggs to be released without any changes in cycle length or frequency.\n', 'BULLET::::- Gynecologic ultrasonography, specifically looking for small ovarian follicles. These are believed to be the result of disturbed ovarian function with failed ovulation, reflected by the infrequent or absent menstruation that is typical of the condition. In a normal menstrual cycle, one egg is released from a dominant follicle\xa0– in essence, a cyst that bursts to release the egg. After ovulation, the follicle remnant is transformed into a progesterone-producing corpus luteum, which shrinks and disappears after approximately 12–14 days. In PCOS, there is a so-called "follicular arrest"; i.e., several follicles develop to a size of 5–7\xa0mm, but not further. No single follicle reaches the preovulatory size (16\xa0mm or more). According to the Rotterdam criteria, which are widely used for diagnosis, 12 or more small follicles should be seen in an ovary on ultrasound examination. More recent research suggests that there should be at least 25 follicles in an ovary to designate it as having polycystic ovarian morphology (PCOM) in women aged 18–35 years. The follicles may be oriented in the periphery, giving the appearance of a \'string of pearls\'. If a high resolution transvaginal ultrasonography machine is not available, an ovarian volume of at least 10 ml is regarded as an acceptable definition of having polycystic ovarian morphology instead of follicle count.\n', 'The pear shaped eggs are implanted into the wall of the pouch and surrounded by tissues. Oxygen is able to get through to the eggs through the capillaries. There is placental fluid present which provides the eggs with nutrients and oxygen and removes waste products. The egg yolk which comes from the mother is also full of necessary nutrients. The male secretes the enzyme prolactin which initiates the breakdown of the outer layer of the egg in order for the placental fluid to be produced. Pregnancy only lasts 20-21 days and the male will usually go into labour in the night time. The number of young produced can range from 50-100 and greatly depends on the age of the male. The older males will produce a larger number of offspring. If the male is in a pair that he is familiar with he will be able to mate again within a few hours of giving birth without having any negative health impacts.\n', 'Approximately every 28 days, the pituitary gland releases a hormone that stimulates some of the ova to develop and grow. One ovum is released and it passes through the Fallopian tube into the uterus. Hormones produced by the ovaries prepare the uterus to receive the ovum. The lining of the uterus, called the endometrium, and unfertilized ova are shed each cycle through the process of menstruation. If the ovum is fertilized by sperm, it attaches to the endometrium and the fetus develops.\n', 'Shortly after internal fertilization, the fertilized ovum enters the partially formed egg case located in the oviduct. After the ovum enters, the rest of the egg case forms around it. Shortly after the egg case finishes developing, it is deposited outside the body; common locations include kelp forests and rocky seafloors. Egg cases are typically produced in pairs, each with one fertilized embryo inside, with the exception of a few species that produce egg cases with more than one viable embryo.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To address the question "When the egg is released from the ovary, what is left behind?" we can extract and analyze relevant content from the provided passages. The key concepts that may be unfamiliar or require clarification include:

1. **Follicle and Corpus Luteum**:
   - **Content**: "After ovulation, the follicle remnant is transformed into a progesterone-producing corpus luteum, which shrinks and disappears after approximately 12–14 days."
   - **Role**: This information is crucial as it explains what happens to the ovarian follicle after the egg is released. The follicle, which is a fluid-filled sac containing the egg, transforms into the corpus luteum, which plays a significant role in hormone production (specifically progesterone) to prepare the uterus for potential implantation of a fertilized egg. Understanding this transformation helps clarify what is left behind in the ovary after ovulation.

2. **Oocyte and Germinal Vesicle**:
   - **Content**: "Once a month, one of the ovaries releases a mature egg (ovum), known as an oocyte. The nucleus of such an oocyte is called a 'germinal vesicle.'"
   - **Role**: The term "oocyte" refers to the immature egg before it is released, and the "germinal vesicle" is a specific structure within the oocyte. This knowledge is essential for understanding the developmental stages of the egg and what constitutes the egg itself.

3. **Menstruation and Uterine Lining**:
   - **Content**: "If no conception occurs, the uterine lining as well as blood will be shed during menstruation."
   - **Role**: This passage provides context for what happens if the egg is not fertilized. It highlights the cyclical nature of the reproductive process and the physiological changes that occur in the body, including the shedding of the uterine lining, which is a consequence of the egg's release and subsequent non-fertilization.

4. **Oogenesis**:
   - **Content**: "Over a regular interval, in response to hormonal signals, a process of oogenesis matures one ovum which is released and sent down the Fallopian tube."
   - **Role**: Oogenesis is the biological process that leads to the formation of the ovum. Understanding this process provides insight into how eggs are developed and released, which is essential for comprehending what is happening in the ovaries during the menstrual cycle.

5. **Hormonal Regulation**:
   - **Content**: "Approximately every 28 days, the pituitary gland releases a hormone that stimulates some of the ova to develop and grow."
   - **Role**: This information about hormonal regulation is vital for understanding the timing and control of ovulation. It explains the physiological mechanisms that lead to the release of the egg and the subsequent changes in the ovary.

### Summary of Roles:
The extracted content provides a comprehensive background on the reproductive process, particularly focusing on the events surrounding ovulation. It clarifies the biological structures involved (follicles, corpus luteum, oocytes), the hormonal regulation of egg release, and the consequences of fertilization or lack thereof (menstruation). This knowledge is essential for answering the original question about what is left behind when the egg is released, as it encompasses both the physical remnants (the corpus luteum) and the physiological implications of the egg's release. Understanding these concepts enhances the model's ability to provide a nuanced and accurate response to the question.

Here is an answer generated by a language model with the reasoning process.

knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:
When an egg is released from the ovary during ovulation, it is part of the menstrual cycle in females. The ovary contains structures called follicles, which are fluid-filled sacs that house immature eggs, known as oocytes. Each month, typically one follicle matures and releases an egg. 

Once the egg is released, the remaining structure of the follicle transforms into a structure called the corpus luteum. The corpus luteum is crucial because it produces hormones, primarily progesterone, which are essential for maintaining the uterine lining in preparation for a potential pregnancy. If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum eventually degenerates, leading to a decrease in hormone levels and the shedding of the uterine lining during menstruation.

Understanding the process of oogenesis, which is the maturation of the oocyte into a viable egg, is also important. This process is regulated by hormonal signals from the pituitary gland, which stimulates the development of the follicles and the release of the egg approximately every 28 days.

In summary, when the egg is released from the ovary, the primary structure left behind is the corpus luteum, which plays a vital role in hormone production and the menstrual cycle. If the egg is not fertilized, the corpus luteum will eventually shrink and disappear, leading to menstruation.

### Answer:
The corpus luteum is left behind in the ovary after the egg is released.

This emphasizes the role of the ovarian follicles in the reproductive process and what remains after ovulation.

### Final Answer:

When the egg is released from the ovary during ovulation, the structure that is left behind is the corpus luteum, which is the remnant of the dominant follicle. If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum will eventually degenerate, leading to menstruation.

The lining of the uterus, called the endometrium, and unfertilized ova are shed each cycle through the process of menstruation. If the ovum is fertilized by sperm, it attaches to the endometrium and the fetus develops.
', 'Shortly after internal fertilization, the fertilized ovum enters the partially formed egg case located in the oviduct. After the ovum enters, the rest of the egg case forms around it. Shortly after the egg case finishes developing, it is deposited outside the body; common locations include kelp forests and rocky seafloors. Egg cases are typically produced in pairs, each with one fertilized embryo inside, with the exception of a few species that produce egg cases with more than one viable embryo.
']

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate key information from the provided passages regarding the process of ovulation and what is left behind after an egg is released from the ovary. Here’s a summary of the relevant information:

### Consolidated Information:
1. **Ovulation Process**:
   - Ovulation is the release of a mature egg (ovum) from the ovarian follicles.
   - This process occurs approximately every 28 days, regulated by hormonal signals from the pituitary gland.
   - The egg is swept into the fallopian tube by fimbria after being released.

2. **Follicle Remnants**:
   - After the egg is released, the follicle from which it was released transforms into a structure known as the corpus luteum.
   - The corpus luteum produces progesterone and eventually shrinks and disappears after about 12–14 days if fertilization does not occur.

3. **Menstruation**:
   - If the egg is not fertilized, it disintegrates or dissolves in the fallopian tube.
   - The uterine lining (endometrium) thickens to prepare for a potential fertilized egg, and if fertilization does not occur, both the endometrium and the unfertilized egg are shed during menstruation.

4. **Oogenesis**:
   - Oogenesis is the process by which ova are formed in the ovaries, and it involves the maturation of one ovum each cycle.
   - The remaining ovarian cells and structures play a role in the reproductive cycle, even if one ovary is absent or dysfunctional.

### Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:
1. **Understanding Causality**:
   - The model can learn the causal relationships between hormonal signals, ovulation, and the subsequent transformations of ovarian structures (follicles to corpus luteum).
   - Recognizing that the release of the egg leads to specific physiological changes (e.g., thickening of the endometrium) helps in understanding biological processes.

2. **Temporal Relationships**:
   - The information about the timing of ovulation (approximately every 28 days) and the lifespan of the corpus luteum (12–14 days) allows the model to infer temporal sequences in biological events.

3. **Consequences of Events**:
   - The model can infer that the absence of fertilization leads to specific outcomes (disintegration of the egg, shedding of the endometrium), enhancing its ability to predict consequences based on initial conditions.

4. **Integration of Biological Processes**:
   - By understanding the interconnectedness of ovulation, hormonal regulation, and menstruation, the model can better grasp complex biological systems and their feedback mechanisms.

5. **Logical Inference**:
   - The model can apply logical reasoning to deduce that if an egg is released and not fertilized, then menstruation will occur, thus linking cause and effect in reproductive health.

### Conclusion:
By consolidating and analyzing the extracted information, the model can improve its causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities. This understanding of biological processes not only enhances the model's knowledge base but also equips it to make informed predictions and inferences about reproductive health and related phenomena.

Here is an answer generated by a language model with the reasoning process.
question:
When the egg is released from the ovary, what is left behind?
answer:
Reasoning process:
When an egg is released from the ovary during the process of ovulation, it is part of the menstrual cycle in females. The ovary contains follicles, which are fluid-filled sacs that house immature eggs (oocytes). Each month, typically one follicle matures and releases an egg. Once the egg is released, the remaining structure of the follicle transforms into a structure called the corpus luteum. The corpus luteum produces hormones, primarily progesterone, which are essential for maintaining the uterine lining in case of pregnancy. If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum eventually degenerates.

Answer:
The corpus luteum is left behind in the ovary after the egg is released.

### Consolidated Information:
1. **Ovulation Process**:

   - This process occurs approximately every 28 days, regulated by hormonal signals from the pituitary gland.

3. **Menstruation**:

### Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:

Generation Format:
knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:
When an egg is released from the ovary during ovulation, it is part of the menstrual cycle, which is a complex interplay of hormonal signals and physiological changes. The ovary contains follicles, which are fluid-filled sacs that house immature eggs (oocytes). Typically, one follicle matures each month and releases an egg. 

Once the egg is released, the remaining structure of the follicle transforms into the corpus luteum. This structure is crucial as it produces hormones, primarily progesterone, which are essential for maintaining the uterine lining (endometrium) in preparation for a potential pregnancy. If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum degenerates after about 12–14 days, leading to a decrease in progesterone levels. This hormonal drop triggers the shedding of the uterine lining and the unfertilized egg during menstruation.

Additionally, the egg itself, if not fertilized, disintegrates or dissolves in the fallopian tube. The entire process is regulated by hormonal signals from the pituitary gland, which orchestrates the timing of ovulation and the subsequent changes in the reproductive system.

Understanding these processes allows us to infer that the release of the egg is not an isolated event; it is part of a cyclical process that involves the transformation of ovarian structures and the preparation of the uterus for potential implantation. The model can thus recognize that if an egg is released and not fertilized, it leads to specific physiological outcomes, including the degeneration of the corpus luteum and the onset of menstruation.

### Answer:
The corpus luteum is left behind in the ovary after the egg is released. If the egg is not fertilized, it will disintegrate, and the corpus luteum will eventually degenerate, leading to the shedding of the uterine lining during menstruation.

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
When the egg is released from the ovary, what is left behind?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['After being released from the ovary, the egg is swept into the fallopian tube by the fimbria, which is a fringe of tissue at the end of each fallopian tube. After about a day, an unfertilized egg will disintegrate or dissolve in the fallopian tube.\n', 'The release of an oocyte does not alternate between the two ovaries and seems to be random. After removal of an ovary, the remaining one produces an egg every month.\n', 'Once a month, one of the ovaries releases a mature egg (ovum), known as an oocyte. The nucleus of such an oocyte is called a "germinal vesicle (see picture)."\n', 'Ovulation is the release of eggs from the ovaries. In humans, this event occurs when the ovarian follicles rupture and release the secondary oocyte ovarian cells. After ovulation, during the luteal phase, the egg will be available to be fertilized by sperm. In addition, the uterine lining (endometrium) is thickened to be able to receive a fertilized egg. If no conception occurs, the uterine lining as well as blood will be shed during menstruation.\n', 'The ova, which are the female sex cells, are much larger than the sperm and are normally formed within the ovaries of the fetus before its birth. They are mostly fixed in location within the ovary until their transit to the uterus, and contain nutrients for the later zygote and embryo. Over a regular interval, in response to hormonal signals, a process of oogenesis matures one ovum which is released and sent down the Fallopian tube. If not fertilized, this egg is released through menstruation in humans and other great apes, and reabsorbed in other mammals in the estrus cycle.\n', 'Usually, ovulation occurs in one of the two ovaries releasing an egg each menstrual cycle; however, if there was a case where one ovary was absent or dysfunctional then the other ovary would continue providing eggs to be released without any changes in cycle length or frequency.\n', 'BULLET::::- Gynecologic ultrasonography, specifically looking for small ovarian follicles. These are believed to be the result of disturbed ovarian function with failed ovulation, reflected by the infrequent or absent menstruation that is typical of the condition. In a normal menstrual cycle, one egg is released from a dominant follicle\xa0– in essence, a cyst that bursts to release the egg. After ovulation, the follicle remnant is transformed into a progesterone-producing corpus luteum, which shrinks and disappears after approximately 12–14 days. In PCOS, there is a so-called "follicular arrest"; i.e., several follicles develop to a size of 5–7\xa0mm, but not further. No single follicle reaches the preovulatory size (16\xa0mm or more). According to the Rotterdam criteria, which are widely used for diagnosis, 12 or more small follicles should be seen in an ovary on ultrasound examination. More recent research suggests that there should be at least 25 follicles in an ovary to designate it as having polycystic ovarian morphology (PCOM) in women aged 18–35 years. The follicles may be oriented in the periphery, giving the appearance of a \'string of pearls\'. If a high resolution transvaginal ultrasonography machine is not available, an ovarian volume of at least 10 ml is regarded as an acceptable definition of having polycystic ovarian morphology instead of follicle count.\n', 'The pear shaped eggs are implanted into the wall of the pouch and surrounded by tissues. Oxygen is able to get through to the eggs through the capillaries. There is placental fluid present which provides the eggs with nutrients and oxygen and removes waste products. The egg yolk which comes from the mother is also full of necessary nutrients. The male secretes the enzyme prolactin which initiates the breakdown of the outer layer of the egg in order for the placental fluid to be produced. Pregnancy only lasts 20-21 days and the male will usually go into labour in the night time. The number of young produced can range from 50-100 and greatly depends on the age of the male. The older males will produce a larger number of offspring. If the male is in a pair that he is familiar with he will be able to mate again within a few hours of giving birth without having any negative health impacts.\n', 'Approximately every 28 days, the pituitary gland releases a hormone that stimulates some of the ova to develop and grow. One ovum is released and it passes through the Fallopian tube into the uterus. Hormones produced by the ovaries prepare the uterus to receive the ovum. The lining of the uterus, called the endometrium, and unfertilized ova are shed each cycle through the process of menstruation. If the ovum is fertilized by sperm, it attaches to the endometrium and the fetus develops.\n', 'Shortly after internal fertilization, the fertilized ovum enters the partially formed egg case located in the oviduct. After the ovum enters, the rest of the egg case forms around it. Shortly after the egg case finishes developing, it is deposited outside the body; common locations include kelp forests and rocky seafloors. Egg cases are typically produced in pairs, each with one fertilized embryo inside, with the exception of a few species that produce egg cases with more than one viable embryo.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that may be contradictory to the model's existing knowledge. 
Identify information that, when added, could update the model's knowledge and prevent factual errors, alleviating model illusions. 
Note that these passages are retrieved from the most authoritative knowledge repositories, so they are assumed to be correct.

To address the question "When the egg is released from the ovary, what is left behind?" and to identify potentially contradictory or updating information from the provided passages, we can analyze the content as follows:

1. **Corpus Luteum Formation**: 
   - Passage 8 states that "the follicle remnant is transformed into a progesterone-producing corpus luteum, which shrinks and disappears after approximately 12–14 days." This indicates that when the egg is released, the follicle from which it came does not simply disappear; instead, it transforms into the corpus luteum, which plays a crucial role in hormone production during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle. This detail is essential for understanding the physiological changes that occur post-ovulation.

2. **Ovarian Follicle Dynamics**:
   - Passage 2 mentions that "the release of an oocyte does not alternate between the two ovaries and seems to be random." This could update the model's understanding of ovarian function, emphasizing that the process is not strictly alternating and can vary from cycle to cycle.

3. **Menstrual Cycle and Shedding**:
   - Passage 4 discusses that "if no conception occurs, the uterine lining as well as blood will be shed during menstruation." This reinforces the understanding that the egg's release is part of a larger cycle that includes the preparation and potential shedding of the uterine lining if fertilization does not occur.

4. **Oocyte and Follicle Relationship**:
   - Passage 5 states that "the ova, which are the female sex cells, are much larger than the sperm and are normally formed within the ovaries of the fetus before its birth." This emphasizes the developmental aspect of oocytes and their relationship with ovarian follicles, which may not be fully captured in a model that focuses solely on the ovulation event.

5. **Hormonal Regulation**:
   - Passage 9 mentions that "approximately every 28 days, the pituitary gland releases a hormone that stimulates some of the ova to develop and grow." This highlights the hormonal regulation involved in the ovulation process, which is crucial for understanding the timing and mechanics of egg release.

In summary, the following key points could update the model's knowledge and prevent factual errors regarding what is left behind when an egg is released from the ovary:

- The transformation of the follicle into a corpus luteum after egg release.
- The random nature of which ovary releases an egg.
- The relationship between egg release and the menstrual cycle, including the shedding of the uterine lining if fertilization does not occur.
- The developmental background of oocytes and their formation in the ovaries.
- The hormonal regulation of the ovulation process.

Incorporating these details would provide a more comprehensive understanding of the physiological processes involved in ovulation and the subsequent changes in the ovaries and uterus.

The corpus luteum produces hormones, primarily progesterone, which are essential for maintaining the uterine lining in case of pregnancy. If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum eventually degenerates.

Generation Format:
knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

When an egg is released from the ovary during ovulation, it is part of the menstrual cycle in females. The ovary contains follicles, which are fluid-filled sacs that house immature eggs (oocytes). Each month, typically one follicle matures and releases an egg. Upon the release of the egg, the remaining structure of the follicle transforms into a structure called the corpus luteum. This transformation is crucial as the corpus luteum produces hormones, primarily progesterone, which are essential for maintaining the uterine lining in case of pregnancy. If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum eventually degenerates after approximately 12–14 days.

Additionally, it is important to note that the release of an oocyte does not alternate between the two ovaries and can vary from cycle to cycle. This randomness in which ovary releases the egg is a significant aspect of ovarian function. The egg's release is also part of a larger cycle that includes the preparation of the uterine lining, which will be shed during menstruation if fertilization does not occur. Furthermore, the ova, which are the female sex cells, are formed within the ovaries of the fetus before birth, highlighting the developmental aspect of oocytes. The hormonal regulation of the ovulation process, primarily driven by the pituitary gland, stimulates the development and release of the ova approximately every 28 days.

In summary, when the egg is released from the ovary, the corpus luteum is left behind, which plays a vital role in hormone production and the menstrual cycle.

**Answer:**
The corpus luteum is left behind in the ovary after the egg is released.

question_info.question: When the egg is released from the ovary, what is left behind?
passages:
After being released from the ovary, the egg is swept into the fallopian tube by the fimbria, which is a fringe of tissue at the end of each fallopian tube. After about a day, an unfertilized egg will disintegrate or dissolve in the fallopian tube.
The release of an oocyte does not alternate between the two ovaries and seems to be random. After removal of an ovary, the remaining one produces an egg every month.
Once a month, one of the ovaries releases a mature egg (ovum), known as an oocyte. The nucleus of such an oocyte is called a "germinal vesicle (see picture)."
Ovulation is the release of eggs from the ovaries. In humans, this event occurs when the ovarian follicles rupture and release the secondary oocyte ovarian cells. After ovulation, during the luteal phase, the egg will be available to be fertilized by sperm. In addition, the uterine lining (endometrium) is thickened to be able to receive a fertilized egg. If no conception occurs, the uterine lining as well as blood will be shed during menstruation.
The ova, which are the female sex cells, are much larger than the sperm and are normally formed within the ovaries of the fetus before its birth. They are mostly fixed in location within the ovary until their transit to the uterus, and contain nutrients for the later zygote and embryo. Over a regular interval, in response to hormonal signals, a process of oogenesis matures one ovum which is released and sent down the Fallopian tube. If not fertilized, this egg is released through menstruation in humans and other great apes, and reabsorbed in other mammals in the estrus cycle.
Usually, ovulation occurs in one of the two ovaries releasing an egg each menstrual cycle; however, if there was a case where one ovary was absent or dysfunctional then the other ovary would continue providing eggs to be released without any changes in cycle length or frequency.
BULLET::::- Gynecologic ultrasonography, specifically looking for small ovarian follicles. These are believed to be the result of disturbed ovarian function with failed ovulation, reflected by the infrequent or absent menstruation that is typical of the condition. In a normal menstrual cycle, one egg is released from a dominant follicle – in essence, a cyst that bursts to release the egg. After ovulation, the follicle remnant is transformed into a progesterone-producing corpus luteum, which shrinks and disappears after approximately 12–14 days. In PCOS, there is a so-called "follicular arrest"; i.e., several follicles develop to a size of 5–7 mm, but not further. No single follicle reaches the preovulatory size (16 mm or more). According to the Rotterdam criteria, which are widely used for diagnosis, 12 or more small follicles should be seen in an ovary on ultrasound examination. More recent research suggests that there should be at least 25 follicles in an ovary to designate it as having polycystic ovarian morphology (PCOM) in women aged 18–35 years. The follicles may be oriented in the periphery, giving the appearance of a 'string of pearls'. If a high resolution transvaginal ultrasonography machine is not available, an ovarian volume of at least 10 ml is regarded as an acceptable definition of having polycystic ovarian morphology instead of follicle count.
The pear shaped eggs are implanted into the wall of the pouch and surrounded by tissues. Oxygen is able to get through to the eggs through the capillaries. There is placental fluid present which provides the eggs with nutrients and oxygen and removes waste products. The egg yolk which comes from the mother is also full of necessary nutrients. The male secretes the enzyme prolactin which initiates the breakdown of the outer layer of the egg in order for the placental fluid to be produced. Pregnancy only lasts 20-21 days and the male will usually go into labour in the night time. The number of young produced can range from 50-100 and greatly depends on the age of the male. The older males will produce a larger number of offspring. If the male is in a pair that he is familiar with he will be able to mate again within a few hours of giving birth without having any negative health impacts.
Approximately every 28 days, the pituitary gland releases a hormone that stimulates some of the ova to develop and grow. One ovum is released and it passes through the Fallopian tube into the uterus. Hormones produced by the ovaries prepare the uterus to receive the ovum. The lining of the uterus, called the endometrium, and unfertilized ova are shed each cycle through the process of menstruation. If the ovum is fertilized by sperm, it attaches to the endometrium and the fetus develops.
Shortly after internal fertilization, the fertilized ovum enters the partially formed egg case located in the oviduct. After the ovum enters, the rest of the egg case forms around it. Shortly after the egg case finishes developing, it is deposited outside the body; common locations include kelp forests and rocky seafloors. Egg cases are typically produced in pairs, each with one fertilized embryo inside, with the exception of a few species that produce egg cases with more than one viable embryo.
